canonical_explanation.text: Lenses are transparent optical devices that refract light. Convex (converging) lenses are thicker at the center and converge parallel rays to a focus. Concave (diverging) lenses are thinner at the center and diverge parallel rays. The lens formula is 1/f = 1/v - 1/u, where f is focal length, v is image distance, and u is object distance. Magnification m = v/u = h'/h. Power of lens P = 1/f (in meters), measured in Dioptres (D). Convex lenses have positive power; concave lenses have negative power.
rules: Convex lens: converges light, thicker at center
Concave lens: diverges light, thinner at center
Sign convention: distances measured from optical center
Power P = 1/f (f in meters), unit: Dioptre (D)
Convex lens: positive power, Concave lens: negative power
Real image: formed on opposite side, inverted
Virtual image: formed on same side, erect

questions.question_text: A convex lens is also known as:
questions.explanation_correct: A convex lens is also known as a converging lens because it is thicker at the center and can focus parallel rays of light to a single point, or focus. This is the defining characteristic of a convex lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A convex lens is not a diverging lens, which is thinner at the center and causes parallel rays to spread out. It is also not a plane lens, which has flat surfaces and does not refract light, or a cylindrical lens, which has a curved surface in only one direction.

questions.question_text: A concave lens is:

options.text: Thicker at edges and center equally

questions.explanation_correct: A concave lens is thinner at the center compared to the edges. This causes the lens to diverge or spread out the parallel rays of light that pass through it, instead of converging them like a convex lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave lens is not thicker at the center or uniform throughout. It is thinner at the center and gets thicker towards the edges. This shape causes the lens to diverge or spread out the parallel rays of light that pass through it, instead of converging them like a convex lens.

questions.question_text: The lens formula is:
questions.explanation_correct: The lens formula is 1/f = 1/v - 1/u, where f is the focal length, v is the image distance, and u is the object distance. This formula accurately describes the relationship between these three quantities for a lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct lens formula is 1/f = 1/v - 1/u, not 1/f = 1/u + 1/v or 1/f = 1/u - 1/v. This formula shows that the image distance (v) and object distance (u) are inversely related to the focal length (f) of the lens. It is important to understand this relationship to use lenses effectively.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of power of a lens is:
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a lens is measured in Dioptres (D), which is the SI unit for the power of a lens. The power of a lens is defined as the reciprocal of its focal length in meters, so the unit Dioptre (D) is the correct unit for the power of a lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct units for the power of a lens. Meter (m) is the unit of length, not power. Watt (W) is the unit of power, but it is not the specific unit used for the power of a lens. Joule (J) is the unit of energy, not power. The correct unit for the power of a lens is Dioptre (D), which is the reciprocal of the focal length in meters.

questions.question_text: Power of a lens is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a lens is given by P = 1/f, where f is the focal length of the lens in meters. This is because the power of a lens is the inverse of its focal length, and it is measured in units of Dioptres (D).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the power of a lens is not equal to its focal length. Option B is also incorrect because the power formula uses the focal length in meters, not centimeters. Option D is incorrect because the power is not given by the square of the focal length, but by the inverse of the focal length.

questions.question_text: When an object is placed at infinity in front of a convex lens, the image is formed:
questions.explanation_correct: When an object is placed at infinity in front of a convex lens, the parallel rays from the object will converge at the focus of the lens, so the image will be formed at the focal point of the lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) An object at infinity will not form an image at infinity, C) The image will not be formed at 2 times the focal length (2F), and D) The image will not be formed between the focal point and 2 times the focal length. The correct option is B) At the focus, since parallel rays from an object at infinity converge at the focal point of the lens.

questions.question_text: The image formed by a concave lens is always:
questions.explanation_correct: A concave lens is thinner at the center and causes parallel rays of light to diverge. This results in a virtual, erect, and diminished image being formed on the same side as the object. Option C correctly describes the image formed by a concave lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A and B describe the image formation by a convex lens, which is thicker at the center and converges parallel rays to a focus. Option D is incorrect because a concave lens always produces a virtual and diminished image, not a magnified one.

questions.question_text: Magnification produced by a lens is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: The magnification m of a lens is defined as the ratio of the image distance v to the object distance u, or m = v/u. This formula allows you to calculate the size of the image compared to the size of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not accurately represent the formula for magnification. Option A would give the reciprocal of the magnification, option C adds the object and image distances which does not represent magnification, and option D uses the focal length instead of the object and image distances.

questions.question_text: A convex lens of focal length 20 cm has power:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) +5 D. This is because the power of a lens is given by the formula P = 1/f, where f is the focal length in meters. If the focal length is 20 cm (or 0.2 m), the power of the lens is P = 1/0.2 = +5 Dioptres (D), which is a positive value for a convex lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct. Option B) -5 D is wrong because a convex lens has a positive power. Option C) +20 D is wrong because the power is calculated as 1/f, and f = 20 cm = 0.2 m, giving a power of +5 D. Option D) +0.05 D is wrong because this value does not match the actual power of the lens, which is +5 D.

questions.question_text: A concave lens of focal length 25 cm has power:
questions.explanation_correct: A concave lens has a negative focal length, so its power P = 1/f will be negative. Since the focal length is 25 cm, the power of the lens is -4 D (Dioptres).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A (+4 D) is incorrect because a concave lens has a negative power. Option C (+25 D) is also incorrect because the power is the reciprocal of the focal length, not the focal length itself. Option D (-0.04 D) is incorrect because the power is calculated as 1/f, which is -1/0.25 = -4 D.

questions.question_text: An object is placed at 2F of a convex lens. The image formed is:
questions.explanation_correct: When an object is placed at 2F (2 times the focal length) of a convex lens, the image is formed at 2F, and it is the same size as the object but inverted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not match the given conditions. When an object is placed at 2F, the image is not formed at F (diminished), nor at infinity, nor between F and the optical center. The correct option B is the only one that correctly describes the image formation when the object is placed at 2F of a convex lens.

questions.question_text: An object is placed 30 cm from a convex lens of focal length 15 cm. The image distance is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) 30 cm. Using the lens formula 1/f = 1/v - 1/u, where f = 15 cm, u = -30 cm (since object is placed 30 cm from the lens), we can calculate v = 30 cm, which is the image distance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) 30 cm. This is because the object is placed 30 cm from the convex lens, and the focal length of the lens is 15 cm. Using the lens formula, we can calculate the image distance to be 30 cm. The other options are incorrect because they do not satisfy the given information about the object distance and the focal length of the lens.

questions.question_text: For a convex lens to form a virtual image, the object must be placed:
questions.explanation_correct: For a convex lens to form a virtual image, the object must be placed between the lens's focal point (F) and the optical center of the lens. This is because the lens will refract the light rays in such a way that they diverge and create a virtual, upright, and magnified image of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Placing the object at infinity would create a real, inverted, and diminished image at the focal point (F) of the lens. B) Placing the object beyond 2F would create a real, inverted, and diminished image between F and 2F. D) Placing the object at 2F would create a real, inverted, and the same size image at 2F.

questions.question_text: If magnification is -2, the image is:
questions.explanation_correct: If the magnification is -2, the image is real and magnified. This is because a magnification less than -1 (but greater than -infinity) indicates that the image is real and magnified.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) A magnification of -2 means the image is real, not virtual. C) A magnification of -2 means the image is magnified, not diminished. D) A magnification of -2 means the image is real, not virtual.

questions.question_text: Two lenses of power +3 D and -1 D are placed in contact. The combined power is:
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a lens is given by the formula P = 1/f, where f is the focal length of the lens. When two lenses are placed in contact, their powers add up. A lens with power +3 D has a focal length of 1/3 meters, and a lens with power -1 D has a focal length of -1 meter. Adding these powers gives a combined power of +2 D, which corresponds to the correct answer of option B.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly add the powers of the two lenses. Option A adds the absolute values of the powers, which is incorrect. Option C assumes the powers subtract, which is also wrong. Option D only considers the power of the first lens, ignoring the second lens. The correct way to find the combined power is to add the individual powers, as explained in the correct explanation.

questions.question_text: An object is placed 15 cm from a convex lens of focal length 10 cm. The magnification is:
questions.explanation_correct: The magnification of a convex lens is given by the formula m = v/u, where v is the image distance and u is the object distance. With the object placed 15 cm from the lens with a focal length of 10 cm, the magnification comes out to be -2, which matches option A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options B, C, and D do not correctly calculate the magnification. Option B (+2) is incorrect because the magnification of a real, inverted image formed by a convex lens is always negative. Option C (-0.5) is incorrect because the magnification formula gives a value of -2. Option D (+0.5) is incorrect because it does not match the actual magnification calculated using the lens formula.

questions.question_text: An object is placed 20 cm from a concave lens of focal length 10 cm. The image distance is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) -6.67 cm. This is because a concave lens has a negative focal length, and when an object is placed in front of a concave lens, the image is formed behind the lens and is virtual, erect, and smaller than the object. Using the lens formula 1/f = 1/v - 1/u, with f = -10 cm and u = -20 cm, we get v = -6.67 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is A) -6.67 cm, not the other options. Option B) +6.67 cm is incorrect because the image formed by a concave lens is virtual and behind the lens, not in front of it. Options C) -20 cm and D) +20 cm are also incorrect because they do not match the correct image distance calculated using the lens formula.

questions.question_text: A lens has power -2.5 D. Its focal length is:
questions.explanation_correct: The lens has a power of -2.5 D, which means it is a concave (diverging) lens. The formula for focal length of a lens is f = 1/P, where f is the focal length in meters and P is the power in Dioptres (D). Plugging in the value of -2.5 D, we get the focal length as -40 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is option B) -40 cm. The key here is that a lens with power -2.5 D is a concave (diverging) lens, which has a negative focal length. Using the formula f = 1/P, the focal length comes out to be -40 cm. Options A), C) and D) are all positive focal lengths, which do not match the negative power of the lens.

questions.question_text: A magnifying glass uses a convex lens with object placed:
questions.explanation_correct: A magnifying glass uses a convex lens with the object placed between the focus and the optical center, as this arrangement produces a larger, magnified image of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not correct because: A) Placing the object at the focus would produce a parallel beam of light, not a magnified image. B) Placing the object beyond 2F would produce an inverted, real image, not a magnified image. D) Placing the object at 2F would produce a real, same-size image, not a magnified image.

questions.question_text: The optical center of a lens is the point through which:
questions.explanation_correct: The optical center of a lens is the point through which light passes without any deviation or bending. This is because the lens is thinnest at the optical center, so light rays passing through it experience minimal refraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The optical center of a lens is not the point where all rays converge, as this is the focus of a convex lens. It is also not the point where parallel rays meet, as this is the focal point of the lens. The maximum refraction occurs at the curved surfaces of the lens, not at the optical center.

questions.question_text: When object is at F of a convex lens, the image is:
questions.explanation_correct: When the object is placed at the focal point (F) of a convex lens, the rays of light from the object become parallel after passing through the lens. This means the image is formed at infinity, or in other words, the image is at infinity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image is not formed at the focal point (F) of the convex lens, as the rays of light become parallel after passing through the lens when the object is placed at F. The image is formed at infinity, not at the focal point or any other specific location. The correct option is that the image is formed at infinity when the object is placed at the focal point of a convex lens.

questions.question_text: For a lens, if v = +30 cm and u = -10 cm, the focal length is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is A) +7.5 cm. This is because the lens formula is 1/f = 1/v - 1/u, where f is the focal length, v is the image distance, and u is the object distance. Substituting the given values, we get 1/f = 1/30 - 1/-10, which simplifies to 1/f = 1/30 + 1/10 = 3/30 = 1/10, or f = +10 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not match the focal length calculated from the lens formula. Option B) -7.5 cm is incorrect because the focal length of a convex lens is positive, not negative. Options C) +20 cm and D) -20 cm are also incorrect because they do not satisfy the lens formula with the given values of v and u.

questions.question_text: Principal focus of a concave lens is:
questions.explanation_correct: The principal focus of a concave lens is virtual, meaning the light rays appear to come from a point behind the lens, even though they do not actually intersect there. This is because a concave lens diverges (spreads out) parallel rays of light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The principal focus of a concave lens is not real because a real focus is formed by converging light rays, but a concave lens diverges light. It is also not at infinity or at the lens itself, as the principal focus is a virtual point behind the lens where the diverging rays appear to originate from.

questions.question_text: A lens of power +2 D has focal length:
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a lens is given by the formula P = 1/f, where f is the focal length of the lens. A lens with power +2 D has a focal length of 0.5 m, as 1/f = 2 D = 2 m^-1, so f = 0.5 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because a lens with power +2 D has a focal length of 0.5 m, not 2 m. Option C is incorrect because 20 cm is equal to 0.2 m, which does not match the focal length of 0.5 m. Option D is incorrect because 2 cm is equal to 0.02 m, which is much smaller than the actual focal length.

questions.question_text: A convex lens is used in:
questions.explanation_correct: A convex lens is used in a magnifying glass because it converges light rays, allowing the viewer to see an enlarged image of the object. This is because convex lenses have a positive power and can focus light to a point, which is the key property of a magnifying glass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex lenses are not used in spectacles for myopia (near-sightedness), as these require concave lenses to diverge light and correct the vision. Convex lenses are also not used in car side mirrors or security mirrors, as these typically use concave mirrors to create a wider field of view.

questions.question_text: The magnification produced by a concave lens is always:
questions.explanation_correct: The magnification produced by a concave lens is always less than 1, meaning the image is smaller than the object. This is because concave lenses are thinner at the center and cause parallel light rays to diverge, creating a virtual and smaller image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The magnification produced by a concave lens is not greater than 1, because concave lenses make the image appear smaller than the object. The magnification is also not equal to 1, as that would mean the image and object are the same size. Concave lenses always produce a magnification that is less than 1, resulting in a smaller image.

questions.question_text: An object 4 cm high is placed 20 cm from a convex lens of focal length 10 cm. The height of the image is:
questions.explanation_correct: The height of the image is 4 cm, which is the same as the object height. This is because for a convex lens, the magnification formula m = v/u = h'/h, where h is the object height and h' is the image height. Since the object distance u = 20 cm and the focal length f = 10 cm, the magnification is 1, which means the image height is the same as the object height.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 4 cm. The magnification of a convex lens is given by the formula m = v/u, where v is the image distance and u is the object distance. In this case, u = 20 cm and f = 10 cm, so the magnification is 1, meaning the image height is the same as the object height of 4 cm. The other options like 8 cm, 2 cm, and 6 cm are incorrect because they do not match the actual image height.

questions.question_text: The power of a plane glass is:
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a plane glass is 0 Dioptres (D) because a plane glass has a flat surface and does not converge or diverge light rays. The focal length of a plane glass is infinite, so its power is 1/f = 0 D.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The power of a lens is measured in Dioptres (D) and is equal to 1 divided by the focal length of the lens in meters. Convex lenses have positive power, while concave lenses have negative power. However, a plane glass is neither convex nor concave, so its power is 0 D, not +1 D or -1 D.

questions.question_text: For photographing distant objects, the film in a camera is placed:
questions.explanation_correct: For photographing distant objects, the film in a camera is placed at the focus of the lens. This is because the lens forms a real, inverted image of the distant object at its focal point, and the film is placed there to capture this focused image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The film is not placed at the optical center of the lens, as that is just the midpoint of the lens and does not form any image. Placing the film at 2F or beyond 2F would result in a smaller, inverted image, which is not ideal for photographing distant objects. The best position is at the focal point of the lens, where a clear, focused image of the distant object is formed.

questions.question_text: A ray passing through the optical center of a lens:

options.text: Is deviated away from principal axis

questions.explanation_correct: A ray passing through the optical center of a lens passes undeviated because it does not undergo any refraction at the lens surface. The optical center is a special point on the lens where the incident ray continues in the same direction without bending.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Rays passing through the optical center are not deviated towards the principal axis. B) Rays passing through the optical center are also not deviated away from the principal axis. D) Rays passing through the optical center are not reflected back, they simply pass through the lens undeviated.

questions.question_text: A convex lens always produces a real image.
questions.explanation_correct: A convex lens does not always produce a real image. Depending on the position of the object, a convex lens can produce both real and virtual images. If the object is placed beyond the focal point of the lens, the lens will produce a real, inverted image. But if the object is placed between the lens and the focal point, the lens will produce a virtual, upright image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because a convex lens can produce both real and virtual images. Many students may think that a convex lens always produces a real image, but this is not the case. The type of image formed by a convex lens depends on the position of the object relative to the focal point of the lens. If the object is placed beyond the focal point, the lens will produce a real, inverted image. But if the object is placed between the lens and the focal point, the lens will produce a virtual, upright image.

questions.question_text: A concave lens can produce a real image.
questions.explanation_correct: A concave lens is a diverging lens, meaning it causes parallel rays of light to spread out or diverge. As a result, a concave lens can only produce a virtual image, which is an image that appears to be behind the lens and cannot be projected onto a screen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that a concave lens can produce a real image. However, this is not the case. A real image can only be formed by a converging or convex lens, which brings parallel rays of light to a focus. A concave lens, on the other hand, always produces a virtual image that appears to be behind the lens and cannot be projected onto a screen.

questions.question_text: The power of a convex lens is positive.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, the power of a convex lens is positive. Convex lenses are thicker at the center and have the ability to converge parallel rays of light, resulting in a positive focal length. The power of a lens is defined as the reciprocal of its focal length (P = 1/f), so a positive focal length gives a positive power value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The power of a convex lens is not negative. Concave lenses, which are thinner at the center, have a negative focal length and hence a negative power. Convex lenses, on the other hand, have a positive focal length and a positive power value, as they can converge parallel rays of light.

questions.question_text: If magnification is positive, the image is erect.
questions.explanation_correct: If the magnification is positive, the image is erect (upright) relative to the object. This is because a positive magnification indicates that the image is formed on the same side of the lens as the object, resulting in an erect image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The common misconception is that if the magnification is negative, the image is erect. However, this is not the case. A negative magnification indicates that the image is formed on the opposite side of the lens, resulting in an inverted image. Therefore, if the magnification is positive, the image is erect.

questions.question_text: When object is between F and 2F of a convex lens, the image is magnified.
questions.explanation_correct: When the object is between the focal point (F) and twice the focal length (2F) of a convex lens, the image formed is magnified. This is because the image is formed on the same side of the lens as the object, and the image distance is greater than the object distance, resulting in magnification of the image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the object is between the focal point (F) and the lens, the image formed would be virtual, upright, and magnified. However, if the object is placed beyond 2F, the image would be real, inverted, and magnified. Therefore, the statement is incorrect as it only applies when the object is between F and 2F.

questions.question_text: Two lenses of power +5 D and -5 D in contact act as a plane glass.
questions.explanation_correct: Two lenses of equal and opposite power (+5 D and -5 D) in contact will cancel each other out, acting as a plane glass with no optical power. This is because the converging effect of the +5 D lens is exactly balanced by the diverging effect of the -5 D lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If you think the two lenses would not act as a plane glass, you may be assuming that the combined power of the two lenses would be the sum of their individual powers (+5 D + -5 D = 0 D). However, when lenses are placed in contact, their powers get subtracted, not added, leading to a net optical power of 0 D.

questions.question_text: In the lens formula, u is always negative according to sign convention.
questions.explanation_correct: The object distance (u) is considered negative according to the sign convention for lenses. This is because the object is placed to the left of the lens, while the image is formed to the right of the lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because the object distance (u) is always considered negative according to the sign convention for lenses. The sign convention is used to keep track of the direction of the light rays and the position of the object and image. The object is placed to the left of the lens, so the object distance is negative.

questions.question_text: The focal length of a thick lens is longer than that of a thin lens of same material and radii.
questions.explanation_correct: The focal length of a thick lens is shorter than that of a thin lens of the same material and radii. This is because the refracting power of a lens depends on the difference in curvature between the two surfaces. A thick lens has a greater difference in curvature, resulting in a shorter focal length.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. The focal length of a thick lens is actually shorter than that of a thin lens of the same material and radii. This is because the refracting power of a lens depends on the difference in curvature between the two surfaces. A thick lens has a greater difference in curvature, resulting in a shorter focal length. Therefore, the focal length of a thick lens is shorter, not longer, than that of a thin lens.

questions.question_text: The image formed by a concave lens is always smaller than the object.
questions.explanation_correct: The image formed by a concave lens is always smaller than the object. This is because a concave lens is thinner at the center and diverges (spreads out) parallel rays of light, forming a virtual, diminished image of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A common misconception is that the image formed by a concave lens can be larger than the object. However, this is not correct. Concave lenses always form virtual, diminished images, regardless of the object distance. The image is always smaller than the object size.

questions.question_text: A convex lens forms a virtual image when the object is at focus.
questions.explanation_correct: A convex lens forms a real image when the object is at the focal point. This is because parallel rays of light entering the lens will converge to a single point, the focal point, where the real image is formed. When the object is at the focus, the image formed will be virtual, not real.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. A convex lens forms a real image when the object is at the focal point, not a virtual image. This is because the parallel rays of light entering the lens will converge to a single point, the focal point, where the real image is formed. The image formed at the focal point is real, not virtual.

questions.question_text: A convex lens is also called a ___ lens.
questions.explanation_correct: A convex lens is called a converging lens because it is thicker at the center and causes parallel rays of light to converge or come together at a focus point. This focusing effect is the key characteristic of a convex lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave lens is thinner at the center and causes parallel rays of light to diverge or spread out. This is the opposite of a converging lens, which is the correct term for a convex lens. The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'converging'.

questions.question_text: The lens formula is 1/f = 1/v - 1/___.
questions.explanation_correct: The lens formula is 1/f = 1/v - 1/u, where f is the focal length, v is the image distance, and u is the object distance. The missing term in the formula is the object distance u, so the correct answer is 'u'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to leave the blank empty. The lens formula is 1/f = 1/v - 1/u, where f is the focal length, v is the image distance, and u is the object distance. The formula relates these three quantities, and u is the missing term in the given question.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of power of a lens is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of power of a lens is the Dioptre (D), which is the reciprocal of the focal length of the lens in meters (1/f). This is because the power of a lens is defined as the ability of the lens to bend or refract light, and this ability is directly related to the focal length of the lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to say that the SI unit of power of a lens is meters (m). This is not correct because the power of a lens is not measured in terms of the distance that the lens can focus light, but rather in terms of the ability of the lens to bend or refract light. The correct unit for power of a lens is the Dioptre (D), which is the reciprocal of the focal length of the lens in meters (1/f).

questions.question_text: Magnification m = v / ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The magnification formula is m = v/u, where v is the image distance and u is the object distance. This means the magnification depends on the ratio of the image distance to the object distance, so the correct answer is 'u'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The magnification formula is m = v/u, not m = v/f. The focal length 'f' is not used in the magnification formula. The correct answer is 'u', as the magnification depends on the object distance, not the focal length of the lens.

questions.question_text: Power of a lens = 1 / ___ (in meters).
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a lens is defined as the reciprocal of its focal length (P = 1/f). This is because the focal length is a fundamental property that determines how the lens bends and focuses light, and the power is a measure of this focusing ability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The power of a lens is not equal to the object distance (u) or the image distance (v). The power is defined as the reciprocal of the focal length (P = 1/f), which is a measure of how strongly the lens converges or diverges light. The focal length, not the object or image distance, is the key factor in determining the power of a lens.

questions.question_text: A concave lens always forms a ___, erect and diminished image.
questions.explanation_correct: A concave lens is thinner at the center and causes parallel rays of light to diverge or spread out. This means the image formed by a concave lens is always virtual, meaning the image is on the same side as the object and appears smaller (diminished) compared to the actual object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'virtual'. A concave lens does not form a real image - it forms a virtual, erect and diminished image. This is because the lens diverges or spreads out the parallel rays of light, instead of converging them to a focus like a convex lens would. Therefore, the correct answer is 'virtual', not 'real'.

questions.question_text: When object is at 2F of a convex lens, the image is at ___ and same size.
questions.explanation_correct: When the object is placed at 2F (twice the focal length) of a convex lens, the image is formed at 2F on the other side of the lens, and it is the same size as the object. This is because at 2F, the object distance (u) is equal to twice the focal length (f), and the image distance (v) is also twice the focal length, resulting in a magnification (m) of 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the object were placed at 2F of a convex lens, the incorrect answer would be that the image is formed at F (the focal length) and is smaller than the object. This is not correct because the image is actually formed at 2F and is the same size as the object. The correct answer is that the image is formed at 2F and is the same size as the object.

questions.question_text: A lens of focal length 50 cm has power ___ D.
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a lens is given by the formula P = 1/f, where f is the focal length of the lens. Since the focal length of the given lens is 50 cm, or 0.5 m, its power is P = 1/0.5 = 2 Dioptres (D).
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the focal length of the lens is 50 cm, then the power of the lens would be P = 1/0.5 = 2 Dioptres (D). The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is a single numerical value, which in this case is '2'.

questions.question_text: The point through which light passes undeviated is called ___ center.
questions.explanation_correct: The point through which light passes undeviated is called the optical center of a lens. This is because light rays passing through the optical center of a lens do not bend or refract, but pass straight through without any deviation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The point through which light passes undeviated is not called the 'center' of the lens. The correct term is the 'optical center' of the lens. The optical center is a specific point on the lens where light rays pass through without any refraction or bending.

questions.question_text: For lenses in contact, P = P1 + ___.
questions.explanation_correct: For lenses in contact, the total power of the lens system is the sum of the individual powers of the lenses. Therefore, the correct answer is P2, which represents the power of the second lens in the system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The power of a lens system in contact is not the difference between the individual lens powers. The correct answer is P2, which represents the power of the second lens. The total power of the lens system is the sum of the individual powers of the lenses, as each lens contributes to the overall bending of light.

questions.question_text: When object is between F and optical center, convex lens forms a ___ image.
questions.explanation_correct: When the object is between the focus (F) and the optical center of a convex lens, the lens forms a virtual image. This is because the light rays from the object diverge after passing through the lens, instead of converging to a real image point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'virtual'. When the object is between the focus (F) and the optical center of a convex lens, the lens forms a virtual image. This means the image appears to be behind the lens, but it is not actually formed there. The light rays appear to come from the virtual image, but they do not actually converge at that point.

questions.question_text: If magnification is negative, the image is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: If the magnification is negative, it means the image is formed on the opposite side of the lens compared to the object. This indicates that the image is inverted compared to the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the magnification is negative, it means the image is formed on the opposite side of the lens compared to the object. However, this does not necessarily mean the image is upright. The correct answer is that the image is inverted when the magnification is negative.

questions.question_text: Arrange the image positions for convex lens as object moves from infinity to optical center:
questions.explanation_correct: As the object moves from infinity to the optical center of the convex lens, the image position changes from being at infinity, to being at 2F, then between F and 2F, then at the focal point F, and finally becoming a virtual image behind the object. This is the correct sequence of image positions as the object distance changes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect explanation would be to arrange the image positions in a different order, such as: Image at 2F, Image at infinity, Image between F and 2F, Image at focus, Virtual image behind object. This is incorrect because the image positions do not follow the correct sequence as the object moves from infinity to the optical center. The key is to understand how the image position changes with the object distance for a convex lens.

questions.question_text: Arrange these lenses in order of increasing power:
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a lens is inversely proportional to its focal length. So, lenses with shorter focal lengths have higher power, and lenses with longer focal lengths have lower power. Therefore, the order of increasing power is f = 100 cm, f = 50 cm, f = 25 cm, and f = 10 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be f = 10 cm, f = 25 cm, f = 50 cm, and f = 100 cm. This is because the power of a lens is inversely proportional to its focal length, so the lens with the shortest focal length (f = 10 cm) has the highest power, and the lens with the longest focal length (f = 100 cm) has the lowest power.

questions.question_text: Arrange the image sizes for convex lens as object moves from beyond 2F to between F and optical center:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is Diminished, Same size, Magnified, Highly magnified virtual. As the object moves from beyond 2F to between F and optical center, the image size changes from diminished to same size to magnified to highly magnified virtual. This is due to the changing nature of refraction of light through the convex lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be to arrange the image sizes as Diminished, Magnified, Same size, Highly magnified virtual. This is incorrect because as the object moves closer to the lens, the image size first decreases (diminished), then increases (magnified), then remains the same size, and finally becomes a highly magnified virtual image. The correct order reflects the changing nature of refraction as the object distance changes.

questions.question_text: Arrange these steps to find image using lens formula:
ordering_items: Apply sign convention to u and f
correct_answer: Apply sign convention to u and f
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of steps is to first note down the given values for u, f, and other quantities. Then apply the sign convention to u and f. Next, use the lens formula to calculate the image distance v. Finally, calculate the magnification m if needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to first try to calculate v using the lens formula, without first noting down the given values and applying the sign convention. This would not work, as the formula requires the correct sign conventions to be applied to u and f. Only after completing these initial steps can you then plug the values into the lens formula to find v.

questions.question_text: Arrange these focal lengths in order of their power (least to most):
questions.explanation_correct: The power of a lens is inversely proportional to its focal length. Since the concave lens with f = 20 cm has the longest focal length, it has the least power. The plane glass has no power, so it has the next least power. The convex lens with f = 20 cm has more power than the concave lens, and the convex lens with f = 10 cm has the most power.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to arrange the lenses from least to most power as: Plane glass, Convex f = 20 cm, Concave f = 20 cm, Convex f = 10 cm. This is incorrect because the power of a lens is inversely proportional to its focal length. The concave lens with f = 20 cm has the least power, not the most. The convex lens with f = 10 cm has the most power, not the least.

questions.question_text: How does a convex lens differ from a concave lens in terms of shape and effect on parallel light rays?

options.text: Convex is thinner at the center and converges light; concave is thicker at the center and diverges light
Convex is thicker at the center and converges light; concave is thinner at the center and diverges light
Both are thicker at the center but convex converges and concave diverges
Both are thinner at the center but concave converges and convex diverges

questions.explanation_correct: A convex lens is thicker at the center than at the edges and converges parallel light rays to a focal point. A concave lens is thinner at the center than at the edges and diverges parallel light rays so they appear to come from a virtual focus. This fundamental difference in shape leads to opposite effects on light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the shape descriptions. Both lenses do not have the same shape (options C and D are incorrect). The shape directly determines the function: thicker at center (convex) causes convergence, thinner at center (concave) causes divergence.

questions.question_text: How does the power of a convex lens of focal length 20 cm differ from the power of a concave lens of the same focal length?

options.text: Convex has +5 D; concave has -5 D
Convex has -5 D; concave has +5 D

questions.explanation_correct: For a convex lens, f = +20 cm = +0.2 m, so P = 1/0.2 = +5 D (positive power). For a concave lens, f = -20 cm = -0.2 m, so P = 1/(-0.2) = -5 D (negative power). Convex lenses always have positive power and concave lenses always have negative power, even when the magnitude of their focal lengths is the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex and concave lenses of the same focal length magnitude have powers of equal magnitude but opposite signs. Convex lenses have positive power (converging), concave lenses have negative power (diverging). They cannot both be positive or both be negative.

questions.question_text: How does the image formed by a convex lens when the object is at 2F differ from the image when the object is beyond 2F?

options.text: At 2F: same size and inverted; beyond 2F: diminished and inverted
At 2F: magnified and inverted; beyond 2F: same size and inverted
At 2F: virtual and erect; beyond 2F: real and inverted
At 2F: diminished and inverted; beyond 2F: magnified and inverted

questions.explanation_correct: When the object is at 2F, the image is formed at 2F on the other side, same size as the object, and inverted. When the object is beyond 2F, the image is formed between F and 2F, diminished (smaller than object), and inverted. Both images are real, but their sizes differ.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At 2F, the image is same size, not magnified or diminished. Beyond 2F, the image is diminished, not same size or magnified. Both positions produce real and inverted images, not virtual. The key distinction is size: same size at 2F versus diminished beyond 2F.

questions.question_text: How does the nature of the image formed by a concave lens differ from the image formed by a convex lens when the object is between F and the optical center?

options.text: Concave: virtual, erect, diminished; Convex: virtual, erect, magnified
Both form virtual, erect, magnified images
Concave: real, inverted, diminished; Convex: virtual, erect, magnified
Concave: virtual, erect, magnified; Convex: virtual, erect, diminished

questions.explanation_correct: A concave lens always forms a virtual, erect, and diminished image regardless of object position. A convex lens forms a virtual, erect, and magnified image when the object is placed between F and the optical center (this is the magnifying glass principle). Both images are virtual and erect, but they differ in size: diminished for concave, magnified for convex.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The concave lens image is always diminished, not magnified. The convex lens image between F and optical center is magnified (this is how a magnifying glass works). They do not produce the same type of image. A concave lens never forms a real image.

questions.question_text: How does the sign of magnification differ for a real image versus a virtual image formed by a lens?

options.text: Real image: positive magnification; virtual image: negative magnification
Real image: negative magnification (inverted); virtual image: positive magnification (erect)
The sign of magnification does not indicate the nature of the image

questions.explanation_correct: For a real image formed by a lens, the magnification m = v/u is negative because v is positive (image on opposite side) and u is negative (object on same side). A negative magnification means the image is inverted. For a virtual image, m is positive because v is negative (image on same side as object), giving an erect image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Real images are inverted (negative m), not erect (positive m). Virtual images are erect (positive m), not inverted (negative m). The sign of magnification directly indicates whether the image is erect or inverted, so option D is wrong.

questions.question_text: A lens is thicker at the center than at the edges, has a positive focal length, and converges parallel rays of light to a point. This lens is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: All three characteristics  thicker at center, positive focal length, and convergence of parallel rays  are defining features of a convex (converging) lens. A concave lens would be thinner at the center, have a negative focal length, and diverge parallel rays.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave lens is thinner at center and diverges light. A plane glass has infinite focal length and no converging power. A cylindrical lens curves in only one direction. Only a convex lens matches all three descriptions.

questions.question_text: A lens has power -4 D. It forms only virtual, erect, diminished images for all object positions. This lens is classified as:

options.text: A convex lens used as a magnifying glass
A convex lens forming real images

questions.explanation_correct: Negative power (-4 D) indicates a diverging lens, which is a concave lens. A concave lens always forms virtual, erect, and diminished images regardless of object position. The focal length would be f = 1/(-4) = -0.25 m = -25 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A convex lens has positive power, not negative. A magnifying glass is a convex lens. A plane mirror is not a lens. Only a concave lens has negative power and always produces virtual, erect, diminished images.

questions.question_text: An image formed by a lens is real, inverted, and the same size as the object. It is formed at a distance of 2F from the lens. The object must be placed:
questions.explanation_correct: When the image is real, inverted, same size as the object, and formed at 2F, the object must also be at 2F. This is a standard case for a convex lens: object at 2F produces an image at 2F on the other side that is the same size, real, and inverted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At infinity, the image forms at F (not 2F) and is highly diminished. At F, the image forms at infinity. Between F and 2F, the image is beyond 2F and magnified. Only at 2F does the image form at 2F with the same size as the object.

questions.question_text: The magnification of an image formed by a lens is +3. Based on this magnification value, the image is:
questions.explanation_correct: A positive magnification (+3) indicates an erect image, which means it is virtual (for a single lens). The magnitude 3 (greater than 1) means the image is magnified  3 times the size of the object. This is the case when an object is between F and the optical center of a convex lens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Positive magnification means erect, not inverted. An erect image formed by a single lens is always virtual. Magnification of 3 means the image is 3 times larger, so it is magnified, not diminished. A virtual image by a lens cannot be inverted.

questions.question_text: Amit places a candle 30 cm from a convex lens of focal length 15 cm. He observes a sharp image on a screen placed on the other side of the lens. The image he sees on the screen is:

options.text: Real, inverted, and same size as the candle

questions.explanation_correct: The object is at 30 cm = 2F (since f = 15 cm). When the object is at 2F of a convex lens, the image is formed at 2F on the other side (30 cm), and it is real, inverted, and the same size as the object. Since the image can be caught on a screen, it is real.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At 2F, the image is the same size, not magnified or diminished. Virtual images cannot be caught on a screen, so the image must be real. Since the object distance equals 2F, this is the special case where image size equals object size.

questions.question_text: Priya's grandmother uses reading glasses with lenses of power +2.5 D. Priya calculates the focal length and type of lens in the glasses. What are her results?
questions.explanation_correct: Positive power (+2.5 D) indicates a convex (converging) lens, used to correct hypermetropia (long-sightedness) common in older people. Focal length f = 1/P = 1/2.5 = 0.4 m = 40 cm. So the glasses have convex lenses of focal length 40 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Positive power means convex lens, not concave. f = 1/P = 1/2.5 = 0.4 m = 40 cm, not 25 cm. Concave lenses have negative power and are used for myopia (short-sightedness). Reading glasses for the elderly are always convex lenses with positive power.

questions.question_text: Rohan places an object 12 cm from a convex lens of focal length 10 cm. Using the lens formula, he calculates the image distance. He then finds that the image is larger than the object. The image distance Rohan calculates is:
questions.explanation_correct: Using the lens formula 1/f = 1/v - 1/u, with f = +10 cm and u = -12 cm: 1/10 = 1/v - 1/(-12), so 1/v = 1/10 - 1/12 = (6-5)/60 = 1/60, giving v = +60 cm. The positive v confirms a real image on the opposite side. Magnification m = v/u = 60/(-12) = -5, confirming a magnified, inverted, real image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image distance must be positive for a real image formed by a convex lens when the object is between F and 2F. Using the lens formula correctly gives v = +60 cm. Negative image distance would indicate a virtual image on the same side as the object, which does not happen when the object is beyond F.

questions.question_text: Meera looks through a concave lens at a tree in the school compound. She notices that the tree appears smaller and upright. No matter how far or near she holds the lens, the tree always appears smaller. Why does this happen?

options.text: Because a concave lens always forms a virtual, erect, and diminished image
Because the tree is very far away
Because a concave lens magnifies objects
Because the lens has zero power

questions.explanation_correct: A concave (diverging) lens always forms a virtual, erect, and diminished image regardless of the object distance. The image is always smaller than the object and appears on the same side as the object. This is an inherent property of concave lenses because they diverge light rays.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tree being far away is not the specific reason  even close objects appear smaller through a concave lens. Concave lenses do not magnify; they diminish. A lens with zero power is a plane glass that does not change image size. The property of always forming diminished images is unique to concave lenses.

questions.question_text: Arjun combines a convex lens of power +3 D with a concave lens of power -1 D by placing them in contact. He then uses this combination to form an image of a distant building. The combined focal length and the nature of the combination are:

options.text: Focal length 50 cm, acts as a converging lens
Focal length 25 cm, acts as a diverging lens
Focal length 50 cm, acts as a diverging lens
Focal length 100 cm, acts as a converging lens

questions.explanation_correct: Combined power P = P1 + P2 = +3 + (-1) = +2 D. Since the combined power is positive, the combination acts as a converging (convex) lens. Focal length f = 1/P = 1/2 = 0.5 m = 50 cm. For a distant building (at infinity), the image forms at the focal point of the combination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The combined power is +2 D (not -2 D or +4 D), giving a focal length of 50 cm (not 25 cm or 100 cm). Positive combined power means the combination acts as a converging lens, not diverging. The powers add algebraically when lenses are in contact.

questions.question_text: A convex lens always forms a real and inverted image EXCEPT when the object is placed:

options.text: Between F and the optical center

questions.explanation_correct: When the object is between F and the optical center, a convex lens forms a virtual, erect, and magnified image (this is the magnifying glass principle). For all other positions  at infinity, beyond 2F, at 2F, between F and 2F, and at F  the convex lens forms real and inverted images (or image at infinity for object at F).
questions.explanation_incorrect: At infinity, the image is real and inverted at F. At 2F, the image is real and inverted at 2F. Beyond 2F, the image is real, inverted, and diminished. Only between F and the optical center does the convex lens break the pattern and form a virtual, erect image. This is the exception that students must remember.

questions.question_text: For a lens, the magnification formula m = v/u gives the correct sign and magnitude EXCEPT when which assumption is violated?

options.text: The lens is thick instead of thin
The sign convention (distances measured from optical center) is not followed
The lens is made of glass instead of plastic
The object is luminous instead of non-luminous

questions.explanation_correct: The magnification formula m = v/u gives correct results only when the standard sign convention is followed: all distances are measured from the optical center, distances in the direction of incident light are positive, and distances opposite to incident light are negative. If sign convention is not followed, the formula gives incorrect magnification values.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula works for thin lenses of any material (glass, plastic, etc.) and for any type of object (luminous or non-luminous). While the thin lens approximation is assumed, the most common source of errors is not applying sign convention correctly. This is the critical exception students must be aware of.

questions.question_text: A concave lens always produces a virtual image. This is true for all object positions EXCEPT:

options.text: When the object is at infinity
When the object is very close to the lens
There is no exception  a concave lens always forms a virtual image for a real object
When the object is at the focus

questions.explanation_correct: There is genuinely no exception for a single concave lens with a real object  it always forms a virtual, erect, and diminished image regardless of where the real object is placed. This is a fundamental property of diverging lenses. Students sometimes think there might be an exception, but there is none.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Even at infinity, a concave lens forms a virtual image (at its focus, on the same side as the object). Even very close to the lens or at the focus, the image remains virtual. The concave lens consistently diverges all light rays, so no real image can ever be formed for a real object.

questions.question_text: Why does a convex lens form a virtual image when the object is placed between F and the optical center, but a real image when the object is beyond F?

options.text: Because the lens changes its shape when the object is close
Because rays from objects between F and optical center diverge after refraction and cannot meet on the other side, so the brain traces them back to form a virtual image
Because the focal length changes when the object is close
Because light cannot pass through the lens when the object is too close

questions.explanation_correct: When the object is between F and the optical center, the refracted rays diverge after passing through the lens  they do not actually converge on the other side. Our brain traces these diverging rays backward to where they appear to come from, creating a virtual image on the same side as the object. When the object is beyond F, refracted rays actually converge to form a real image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lens does not change shape or focal length based on object position  these are fixed physical properties. Light always passes through the lens. The key reason is the geometry of ray refraction: inside F, refracted rays diverge; beyond F, they converge.

questions.question_text: Why is the power of a concave lens negative while the power of a convex lens is positive?

options.text: Because concave lenses are smaller in size
Because a concave lens has a negative focal length (virtual focus), and power = 1/f, so power is also negative
Because the sign convention assigns negative values to all diverging devices arbitrarily

questions.explanation_correct: A concave lens diverges light, so its focus is virtual  on the same side as the incident light. According to sign convention, this virtual focus has a negative distance from the optical center, giving a negative focal length. Since power P = 1/f, a negative f gives negative power. A convex lens has a real focus on the opposite side, giving positive f and positive power.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Size does not determine the sign of power. Lenses do not absorb light (they refract it). The negative sign is not arbitrary  it follows logically from the sign convention and the physical position of the virtual focus of a diverging lens.

questions.question_text: Why is the object distance (u) always taken as negative in the lens formula?

options.text: Because the object is always on the left side of the lens, opposite to the direction of measurement (positive direction)
Because objects are always smaller than images
Because the lens formula requires u to be negative for mathematical consistency only
Because the object always emits negative light rays

questions.explanation_correct: According to the New Cartesian sign convention, all distances are measured from the optical center of the lens. The direction of incident light (left to right) is taken as positive. Since the object is always placed on the left side (from where light comes), its distance from the optical center is measured in the negative direction (against the positive direction), making u negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Object size has nothing to do with the sign of u. The negative sign is not arbitrary  it follows directly from the sign convention. There is no such thing as negative light rays. The reason is purely geometric: the object is on the side opposite to the positive measurement direction.
